com.camerontec.catalys.util.data

Interface ITagOrderingRegistry

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractTagOrderingRegistry, FastTagOrderingRegistry

    public interface ITagOrderingRegistry
    Stores tag order information used by OrderedTagValues.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int[] getOrdering(int id)
      Each +ve entry represents a tag number, the absolute value of each -ve entry represents a subrecord id.
      int getRecordID(IValue value)
      Return ordering recordID (associated with this registry) corresponding to the given field value.
      int[][] getTagPaths(int id)
      Returns array containing a path for each tag in a given record.

    • Method Detail

      • getTagPaths

        int[][] getTagPaths(int id)
        Returns array containing a path for each tag in a given record.

        Note that this information is redundant. It can be calculated from the ordering (see getOrdering(int). However, it is convenient to have the registry only compute it once and also the array can get large, especially if large tag numbers are involved, so it is best to have a single shared instance of it here in the registry.

        The tag number can be used to index the array.

        Each entry in the array is a path to the given tag in the ordering.

        The path is just the index of the tag in the ordering.

        In a simple OrderedTagValues which is just a list of fields with no nested subrecords, the path will be a single int representing the position of the tag in the list - eg 0 would mean that the tag is first in the ordering.

        In a OrderedTagValues which has contains nested subrecord(s) the path to tags contained in subrecords will contain the index to the location(s) of the subrecord(s) in the list, and then finally the index of the tag within the subrecord to which it belongs.

        For example: (35, 67, 7, (1, (98, 99), 15), 21, 37) This represents an ordering where the main record can contain tags 35, 67 and 7, followed by a subrecord (1, (98, 99), 15), followed by tags 21 and 37. The subrecord consists of tag 1, another subrecord (98,99), then tag 15. Assume that the first subrecord has id 300 and its nested subrecord has id 400. Then the path to tag 98 would be 3, 1, 0. This is because the path to tag 98 is through the record at the element 3, then the subrecord at element 1, and finally the tag is at element 0 of that subrecord.

        Here are the paths of all tags in this ordering: 35 - 0 67 - 1 7 - 2 1 - 3,0 98 - 3,1,0 99 - 3,1,1 15 - 3,2 21 - 4 37 - 5

        Parameters:
        id - ID of record
        Returns:
        Tag paths

      • getOrdering

        int[] getOrdering(int id)
        Each +ve entry represents a tag number, the absolute value of each -ve entry represents a subrecord id. For example: (35, 67, 7, (1, (98, 99), 15), 21, 37) This represents an ordering where the main record can contain tags 35, 67 and 7, followed by a subrecord (1, (98, 99), 15), followed by tags 21 and 37. The subrecord consists of tag 1, another subrecord (98,99), then tag 15.

        Assume that the top level record has id 100, the first subrecord has id 300 and its nested subrecord has id 400.

        This method would return the following:

        • getOrdering( 100 ): 35, 67, 7, -300, 21, 37
        • getOrdering( 300 ): 1, -400, 15
        • getOrdering( 400 ): 98, 99
        Parameters:
        id - ID of record.
        Returns:
        the ordering

      • getRecordID

        int getRecordID(IValue value)
        Return ordering recordID (associated with this registry) corresponding to the given field value.
        Parameters:
        value - Field value (often FIX message type).
        Returns:
        Ordering record ID.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no such record exists in the registry.
